This patient likely has common variable immunodeficiency (CVID), and serum levels of IgG, IgA, and IgM should be measured to begin evaluation (
). The onset of CVID is usually between the ages of 15 and 25 years, and a history of recurrent respiratory tract infections with encapsulated organisms, such as

, as well as giardiasis are common. Patients with CVID have a higher incidence of autoimmune disorders, particularly autoimmune hemolytic anemia and thrombocytopenia, pernicious anemia, and rheumatoid arthritis, as well as disorders of the gastrointestinal tract leading to diarrhea and malabsorption. A higher incidence of CVID exists in those of northern European ancestry, and there is a familial predisposition to selective IgA deficiency and malignancies. If serum IgG and IgA or IgM levels are low, the antibody response to protein- and polysaccharide-based vaccines should then be assessed. If IgG levels are very low (<200 mg/dL [2 g/L]) or undetectable, assessment of vaccine response is not necessary because antibody levels are predictably absent. Therefore, the first step in the evaluation of patients with suspected CVID is measurement of serum immunoglobulin levels.

However, the first step in evaluating this patient is measurement of immunoglobulins because CVID is the most common cause of severe antibody deficiency in children and young adults.

Defective cell-mediated immunity is typically suggested by the occurrence of severe or prolonged infections with common viruses, opportunistic intracellular pathogens, or fungi. Cutaneous delayed-type hypersensitivity is an in vivo test of cellular immunity. The test measures the ability to react to an intradermal injection of an antigen to which the patient has been previously exposed, such as

). A positive response suggests normal cellular immunity, but a negative response may have many causes and does not establish the diagnosis of impaired cellular immunity. A negative response is usually followed up with flow cytometry and functional assays. This patient's clinical presentation does not suggest an isolated defect in cell-mediated immunity.
